Award.AwardTitle: SusChem: Innovation Inspired by Amides: Oxidative Ni-catalysis, Cascade Acylations, and Green Peptide Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis and the Catalysis Programs are co-funding a project by Professor Vy Maria Dong from the University of California at Irvine that aims to identify environmentally benign and efficient methods for synthetic chemistry. Professor Dong's research team is focused on the study of inexpensive and earth abundant metals as constituents in catalysts that allow the formation of common linkages in organic molecules. The project provides practical methods for making molecules by minimizing both costs and waste. An outreach program created by Professor Dong focuses on a conference/workshop to support and promote women in the field of organic synthesis. This meeting provides an avenue for graduate students in Southern California to network, collaborate, and exchange ideas.

Professor Dong's research project impacts the synthesis of a wide-range of molecules that contain the commonly occurring ester and amide linkage. The use of base-metal catalysts contributes to the nations need for more efficient and sustainable chemistry. The pursuit of oxidative Ni-catalysis is an unexplored mode of reactivity that enables the conversion of aldehydes into esters, amides, and ketones. This platform provides a unique avenue for enantioselective reductions and regioselective acylations. The stereoselective acylations described have the potential to impact synthetic routes to a vast number of natural products that bear chiral ester and acetamido ester motifs. Studies on the mechanism of this catalytic process impact related cooperative catalytic methodology. The final aim pursues an environmentally benign peptide synthesis as a new approach to a central problem in synthesis with widespread applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We thank the National Science Funding agency for funding our project, which focused on inventing more sustainable and green technologies that could be used to build molecular architecture. These structures represent common linkages and motifs found in biologically relevant molecules and materials. Thus, the tools facilitate the discovery of new medicines, materials, and alternative fuels. 

We achieved our three main objectives, which included a greener approach to making cyclic peptides. By using an unsaturated amino acid residue, we could enable ring-closings to occur with 100 less solvent waste than previously known. By using catalysts, we found new ways to coupling feedstock building blocks, such as alkynes and alkenes. In addition, we discovered a new way to break carbon-carbon bonds and turn aldehydes into alkenes. Finally, we pioneered a novel way to use dienes and alkynes via a tandem catalysis strategy. 

Aside from the practical applications of this work, our laboratory gained important insights on how these catalysts function at the level of bonds and atoms. These insights are fundamental and can be used to guide future studies in organic synthesis and catalysis. A total of 12 manuscripts were made possible and acknowledge support from the NSF via this grant and/or through the funding of graduate fellowships. 

Highly trained personnel are another tangible outcome. The students working on these projects were trained for highly competitive positions as molecular architects in the pharmaceutical and agricultural industry. Some went on to academic careers. 

Finally, the PI was involved in carrying out the NSF mission to increase participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences. She mentored URM students and women, as well as participated in many symposia for outreach. We created a social media avenue for young scientists to showcase their work the general public. 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2019
Modified by: Vy Dong
